data.title: Arnold Schwarzenegger’s “Be Useful” — A Brutally Honest Book Review
data.meta_description: In the iconic opening scenes of Pumping Iron, the ballet instructor putting Arnold and Franco through their paces, points out that it’s the in-between moments of the poses that are just as pertinent…
data.text:
In the iconic opening scenes of Pumping Iron, the ballet instructor putting Arnold and Franco through their paces, points out that it’s the in-between moments of the poses that are just as pertinent as hitting the pose itself.

It’s a deliberately incongruous scene purposefully crafted and chosen for both audience impact and illustrative of the lessons forthcoming.

There’s the implication that mastery requires total ownership of one’s craft and highlights that a champion is willing to do whatever it takes to be the best in their field.

It also demonstrates that the moments on stage are about more than just the mandatory poses — the audience is watching and judging those liminal transitions from one movement to the next.

Likewise, on life’s stage, it’s in not just our resume or achievements, but also those in-between moments that we’re being observed and judged for our actions, choices, and values even when we’re free of the spotlight, and think that no one is watching.
